name: Steven Goodwin
title: Owner; Revenue Management / Guest Services Lead; President (iTrip Franchise Association)

flow.context: Steven Goodwin co-owns iTrip Charleston Beaches with his wife Sarah — they've run this iTrip franchise since 2016, covering Isle of Palms, Folly Beach, Kiawah, Seabrook, and greater Charleston. Steven leads revenue management and guest services, and is also President of the iTrip Franchise Association, giving him influence across the entire iTrip network. His background is enterprise hospitality — former Managing Director at Hard Rock Hotels & Casinos, CEO of Hard Rock Park, board roles at Universal Orlando and Universal Studios Japan. The operation is lean but promises professional cleaning and meticulous inspection on every turnover, with a small office team (ops manager Hunter Ray, office manager Megan Corn) coordinating a network of cleaners, inspectors, and vendors via Slack and Google Drive. No direct personal connection to Sam — lead with Charleston market proximity and the franchise operator angle.

call_start.label: FIRST WORDS
call_start.say: Hey, is Steven around? It's Sam.
call_start.note: Say it casually like you've talked before. Don't give a last name or company unless asked. Works whether Steven or a gatekeeper picks up.

branches.label: Gatekeeper asks who's calling or what it's about
'He's not available' / 'Can I take a message?'

gatekeeper_context.label: GATEKEEPER — GIVE CONTEXT
gatekeeper_context.say: Yeah — I work with a few other property managers in the Charleston area. Would you mind letting him know it's Sam Parks?
gatekeeper_context.note: Don't pitch. Don't explain RapidEye. If the voice sounds like a younger woman, this could be Megan Corn (office manager). Stay relaxed.

gatekeeper_social_proof.label: GATEKEEPER — SOCIAL PROOF
gatekeeper_social_proof.say: Totally — we help a couple of vacation rental companies with their inspection workflows. I sent him a note and just wanted to give him a quick heads up. Would you mind passing me through?
gatekeeper_social_proof.note: This is your last shot at getting through the gate. Stay calm, don't oversell. If they say no, take the L gracefully and get a callback time.

branches.label: Still blocked / offers to take a message

gatekeeper_blocked.label: GATEKEEPER — BLOCKED
gatekeeper_blocked.say: No worries at all. When's a good time to try him back? And who am I speaking with, by the way?
gatekeeper_blocked.note: Get the gatekeeper's name and a callback time. Write both down. If they offer voicemail, take it.

voicemail.label: VOICEMAIL
voicemail.say: Hey Steven, it's Sam Parks — I work with a few vacation rental operators in the Charleston beach market on their turnover inspection workflows. Got something I think you'd want to see given the way you guys handle your turnovers. My number is [your number]. Again, Sam Parks. Talk soon.
voicemail.note: Under 20 seconds. Sound like a peer, not a pitch. Don't mention RapidEye by name — curiosity is the goal. Call back in 2 days if no response.

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Steven — I work with a few other vacation rental operators in the Charleston market. It's Sam Parks over at RapidEye. Have you heard my name tossed around?
opener.note: Feet on the desk. You're not pitching — you're calling a peer. Pause after the question and let him answer. Don't rush to fill silence.

branches.label: 'I'm in the middle of something' / bad timing

heard_yes.label: THEY'VE HEARD OF YOU
heard_yes.say: Oh nice — well normally we'd be working together on something like this. What'd you hear?
heard_yes.note: Let him talk. Whatever he says, use it to bridge naturally into the pain trigger.

branches.label: Gives some context or vague recollection

heard_no.label: HAVEN'T HEARD — BRIDGE TO REASON
heard_no.say: Ha — I guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well the reason for my call — I work with a few other property managers running beach vacation rentals, and something keeps coming up around turnover inspections that I thought you'd actually get, especially with the standards you guys hold. Mind if I share what I mean?
heard_no.note: The 'standards you guys hold' references their promise of meticulous inspection on every turnover. Say it naturally — don't say 'I saw on your website.'

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again tomorrow? Or is later this week better?
bad_timing.note: Get a specific callback time. If he gives one, that's a win — write it down and hang up fast.

permission_fallback.label: PERMISSION — ASK FOR 30 SECONDS
permission_fallback.say: Yeah totally — I mean, it is a cold call. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I reached out, and if it's not a fit you can totally hang up on me?
permission_fallback.note: You're acknowledging reality. That disarms people. Smile while you say it.

permission_rejected.label: PERMISSION REJECTED — SPLIT
permission_rejected.say: Shoot — totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is it that you already know what we do and it's just not a fit?
permission_rejected.note: This forces a choice. Most people will say 'bad timing,' which opens the door to a callback. If they say 'not a fit,' exit gracefully.

branches.label: Opens up / asks what you do

bad_timing_callback.label: LOCK IN A CALLBACK
bad_timing_callback.say: Totally get it. When's a better time to try you? I'll block it off so I don't catch you off guard again.
bad_timing_callback.note: Lock in a specific day and time. Even a vague 'try me next week' is a win — note it.

pain_trigger.label: PAIN TRIGGER — THE PROBLEM
pain_trigger.say: So I was talking to another property manager — similar setup to yours, franchise operation, beach properties, managing turnovers across a bunch of units. And the thing that kept coming up was this: their cleaners are taking photos after every turn. Dozens of photos per property. And someone on the team is supposed to review all of them before the next guest checks in. But in reality — especially when summer hits and you've got back-to-back turns — nobody's catching everything. A stain slips through, a deck chair goes missing off the porch, something's cracked that wasn't cracked last week. Guest checks in, sees it, leaves a review about it. And now the owner's calling asking why the home wasn't inspected — even though someone did take a photo of the problem. It just got buried and nobody flagged it. Does that resonate at all with what you guys deal with?
pain_trigger.note: PAUSE after the question. Silence is your friend. Steven leads guest services and revenue — the guest-review and owner-calling lines hit his world directly. Let him react before you say anything else.

branches.label: 'Yeah, that's pretty much it' / agrees / tells a story
'We're not that big' / minimizes the problem

scale_reframe.label: REFRAME FOR LEAN TEAMS
scale_reframe.say: That's actually the thing — the operators who feel this the most aren't the biggest ones. It's the ones running tighter teams. Because when you don't have a huge QA department, every missed issue hits harder. There's no safety net. It's your team — and they're already stretched across cleaning, inspections, guest comms, maintenance dispatch. Does that track?
scale_reframe.note: Steven's team is lean — small office staff plus a vendor network. This reframes 'small' as exactly why the problem matters more, not less.

warm_reaction.label: THEY'RE WARM — STOP PITCHING, START ASKING
warm_reaction.say: Yeah, I figured that'd hit home. So before I get into what we built — what does your inspection process actually look like right now? Are your cleaners taking photos, or do you have separate inspectors going through after them?
warm_reaction.note: STOP SELLING. He's engaged — now learn his process. Their operation appears to run a clean-then-inspect two-step, but find out how it actually works day to day. Listen for names, tools, pain points.

branches.label: Mentions Breezeway or a specific tool
Skips the question / asks what you do

discovery_process.label: DISCOVERY — DIG INTO WORKFLOW
discovery_process.say: Got it. And when something does get flagged — a maintenance issue, damage, something missing — how does that get to the right person? Is that going through Slack or a shared folder, or do you have a more formal system?
discovery_process.note: Their team uses Slack and Google Drive internally. If he mentions either, that's your opening — photos buried in Slack threads is the exact problem. Listen for whether Hunter (ops manager) or Megan (office manager) runs the triage — you may need to loop them in later.

branches.label: Describes workflow / mentions Slack or manual coordination

breezeway_stack_bridge.label: STACK MATCH — INTEGRATION HOOK
breezeway_stack_bridge.say: Oh nice — that's actually one of the platforms we plug directly into. So it'd just sit on top of what you're already doing, zero workflow change. The AI reads the photos coming through and flags anything that looks off — damage, missing items, staging issues — before the next guest checks in.
breezeway_stack_bridge.note: iTrip's platform supports a Breezeway integration at the API level. If he confirms they use Breezeway, this is a slam dunk. If he names something else, adjust: 'We integrate with most of the major platforms — we'd just sit on top of it.'

discovery_franchise_scale.label: DISCOVERY — FRANCHISE EXPANSION ANGLE
discovery_franchise_scale.say: That makes sense. And one thing I'm curious about — I know you're involved with the iTrip Franchise Association. Is this inspection gap something other operators in the network are dealing with too, or is it more of a local challenge?
discovery_franchise_scale.note: This is the expansion play. Steven is President of the franchise association. If he says other operators struggle too, you can position a pilot that could scale across the iTrip network. Don't push — just plant the seed.

branches.label: 'Yeah, it's a common issue across the network'
'How do you know about that?' / surprised
Redirects back to his own operation

franchise_explain.label: EXPLAIN HOW YOU KNOW
franchise_explain.say: I just do my homework before I call someone — I don't like wasting people's time. But honestly, that's part of why I reached out to you specifically versus another operator in the market. You've got the local operation plus the network-wide view. That's pretty rare.
franchise_explain.note: Keep it light and honest. He'll respect the preparation. Don't dwell — bridge right into the solution.

solution_drop.label: ONE-SENTENCE SOLUTION
solution_drop.say: So here's the short version — we built an AI layer that sits on top of the photos and videos your team is already capturing during turnovers. It automatically flags damage, missing items, staging issues, anything that looks different from how the property should look. No extra steps for your cleaners, no new app to learn. It just reads what's already coming in and tells you what needs attention before the guest arrives.
solution_drop.note: One clear explanation, then go straight to the CTA. Don't list features. Don't oversell. Let him react.

branches.label: 'How does it integrate with what we use?'

integration_detail.label: INTEGRATION DETAIL
integration_detail.say: It plugs into whatever you're already using for task management or photo capture — Breezeway, Track, even if your cleaners are just dropping photos in a shared drive. We pull the images, run them through the AI, and push the flagged issues back as a report. Setup's usually a couple days, not weeks.
integration_detail.note: If he's asking about integration, that's buying interest. Answer clearly, then bridge to the meeting — don't try to close on the phone.

cta_meeting.label: ASK FOR THE MEETING
cta_meeting.say: Look, I don't want to sell you something on a cold call. Would you be open to a quick 15-minute demo sometime this week? I can show you exactly how it works with real turnover photos — worst case you steal some ideas for your own process and we part as friends.
cta_meeting.note: Low pressure. 'Steal some ideas and part as friends' gives him a reason to say yes without committing to buy anything. Pause and let him answer.

branches.label: 'I need to talk to my team' / 'Let me check with Sarah'

book_meeting.label: BOOK IT NOW
book_meeting.say: Awesome. I've got next Tuesday and Thursday pulled up — which one works better for you? Morning or afternoon?
book_meeting.note: Give two options, not an open question. Lock the time while you have momentum.

branches.label: 'Let me check my calendar' / 'Just send me an invite'

meeting_hold.label: GET THE INVITE OUT
meeting_hold.say: Totally — what email should I send the invite to? I'll get it over right now while we're on.
meeting_hold.note: Get his direct email and send the invite while still on the phone. Don't let it become 'I'll get back to you.' The known general inbox is charlestonbeaches@itrip.net — push for a personal address.

meeting_booked.label: MEETING CONFIRMED
meeting_booked.say: Perfect — sending that over now. Really appreciate you taking my call, Steven. Talk to you then.
meeting_booked.note: STOP SELLING. You got the meeting. Be gracious, confirm the time, and hang up. Send the calendar invite immediately after.

objection_not_interested.label: OBJECTION — NOT INTERESTED
objection_not_interested.say: Totally get it. And honestly, I should've assumed you'd be all set — otherwise you probably would've reached out to us. Just so nobody on my team cold calls you again... is it more that this just isn't a problem you're focused on right now, or is it more that you just hate cold calls?
objection_not_interested.note: Agree first — surprise him. Then split. Most people pick 'hate cold calls,' which gives you an opening. The 'so nobody calls you again' line incentivizes honesty.

branches.label: 'Not a problem I'm focused on' / 'Not a priority'

split_not_interested.label: DIG INTO PRIORITIES
split_not_interested.say: Makes total sense. What is top of mind for you heading into the summer season? I only ask because the operators I talk to who are focused on reviews and owner retention keep running into this same inspection gap — just curious if it's different for you guys.
split_not_interested.note: Reframe from 'inspection tool' to 'thing that impacts what he IS focused on.' Summer is peak season in Charleston — turnover volume and pressure will spike. If he mentions revenue or growth, go to revenue_bridge.

revenue_bridge.label: TIE INSPECTIONS TO REVENUE
revenue_bridge.say: That makes sense. The reason this keeps coming up with operators focused on revenue is that the biggest drag on owner retention — and your ability to add new properties — is when homes aren't guest-ready and reviews take a hit. That's the piece this solves. But I totally hear you — would you be open to a quick look just so it's on your radar for when it makes sense?
revenue_bridge.note: Connect inspection quality directly to his priority. Owner retention is existential for franchise operators — losing a property is losing recurring revenue.

objection_have_process.label: OBJECTION — ALREADY HAVE SOMETHING
objection_have_process.say: That makes total sense — with your portfolio and the standards you guys hold, you'd have to have something solid in place. Is it more that you're fully covered and happy with how it's working, or is it more that switching anything right now would just be a headache?
objection_have_process.note: Agree and validate — then split. If 'happy,' dig into what happy means. If 'switching is a headache,' RapidEye doesn't replace anything — it layers on top.

branches.label: 'Happy with what we have' / 'It works fine'
'Don't want to switch anything right now'
Names a specific tool they use

split_have_process.label: DIAGNOSE THE CURRENT PROCESS
split_have_process.say: Got it. And just so I understand — is someone on your team manually reviewing all the turnover photos, or does your current system flag issues automatically?
split_have_process.note: This is a diagnostic question. Almost nobody has automatic AI-powered flagging. Their 'process' is almost certainly manual review — which is the gap. If he says 'someone reviews them,' you have the opening.

manual_gap.label: EXPOSE THE GAP — POSITION AS ADDITIVE
manual_gap.say: Yeah — that's exactly the gap I keep hearing about. The photos get taken, but the review is manual, and during high-turn weeks stuff just slips. That's literally the only thing we do — we sit on top of whatever you're already using and flag what a human would miss or just wouldn't have time to catch. It's not a replacement for anything you're doing. It's a layer. Would you be open to a quick look to see if it'd actually add anything for you?
manual_gap.note: Key message: additive, not replacement. This handles the objection by respecting their current process and filling the acknowledged gap.

no_switch_reframe.label: NO SWITCH NEEDED
no_switch_reframe.say: Totally — and that's actually the whole point. We don't replace anything. We literally plug into whatever you're already using and add an AI layer on top of it. Your cleaners keep doing exactly what they're doing, your process stays the same. We just catch what gets missed. Would you be open to a 15-minute look?
no_switch_reframe.note: He's a franchise operator with established workflows — 'no change required' is the message that matters most. Say it clearly and directly.

objection_no_budget.label: OBJECTION — NO BUDGET
objection_no_budget.say: Totally get it. Nowadays it's harder to keep a tool, let alone buy something new — especially running a franchise where every dollar's already accounted for. Just so nobody on my team bugs you again... is it that budget for this cycle is completely locked, or is it more that anything new has to go through an approval process?
objection_no_budget.note: Acknowledge the franchise cost structure — shows you understand his world. Then split to find out if it's timing or process.

branches.label: 'Everything has to go through a process'

sell_test_drive.label: SELL THE TEST DRIVE
sell_test_drive.say: Look — you're probably not buying something from a guy who just cold called you, and I totally respect that. But the property managers who end up using this are the ones who saw it before they actually needed it. Would you be open to a quick 15-minute look — not to buy anything, just so you know what's out there? If nothing else, I can show you what other operators in the Charleston market are doing with their turnover photos. Worst case you steal some ideas.
sell_test_drive.note: This is your last real move for the meeting. Low commitment, high value. The 'other operators in Charleston' creates competitive curiosity — Stay Duvet, Island Realty, Dunes Properties, etc. are all in his market.

send_email.label: SEND ME AN EMAIL — ASK ONE QUESTION
send_email.say: Totally fair. One quick question so I don't send you something generic — what would be most useful to see? Is it more how the AI actually catches stuff, or how it fits into the workflow you already have?
send_email.note: Get his preference so the email is relevant and not just another generic pitch. You're also keeping the conversation going for one more beat.

send_email_confirm.label: LOCK THE EMAIL + PLANT NEXT STEP
send_email_confirm.say: Got it — I'll put something together. What's the best email for you? I'll include a couple times to connect in case you want to see it live after you look it over.
send_email_confirm.note: Push for a direct email, not just the general inbox. charlestonbeaches@itrip.net is the known general address. In the follow-up email, include a specific day and time suggestion and reference this conversation.

referral_or_loop.label: REFERRAL — FIND THE RIGHT PERSON
referral_or_loop.say: For sure — who on your team would typically look at something like this? Is that someone on the ops side, like Hunter, or would it be you and Sarah making the call?
referral_or_loop.note: Dropping Hunter Ray's name (ops manager) shows you know the org without being creepy. Steven will either confirm, correct, or say it's him and Sarah. If it's just the two of them, go straight to booking.

branches.label: Confirms Hunter or names someone else
'Send me something and I'll share it internally'

referral.label: GET THE INTRO
referral.say: Got it. Would it be easier if I reached out to them directly, or would you rather I send you something you can pass along? Either way works for me.
referral.note: Make it easy for him. If he says reach out directly, that's gold — your next call is warm with a Steven Goodwin referral.

referral_confirm.label: GET CONTACT INFO + PERMISSION
referral_confirm.say: Appreciate that. Do you have their direct line or email handy? And is it cool if I mention you pointed me their way?
referral_confirm.note: Get the contact info and explicit permission to name-drop Steven. This turns your next cold call into a warm call.

branches.label: 'I'll have them reach out to you'

graceful_exit.label: END GRACEFULLY
graceful_exit.say: Really appreciate your time, Steven. If anything changes or this comes up down the road, I'm easy to find. Have a good one.
graceful_exit.note: Don't burn the bridge. Be genuine. Immediately after hanging up, note everything from this call — what he said about his process, names mentioned, callback time, email given. Update CRM.
